required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Optimized Cardioprotection Therapy in Obese Subjects With AMI
clinical_study.official_title: Effects and Mechanism of Adipokines Cardiac Protection in Obese Patients With Acute Myocardial Infarction (AMI) Who Have Undergone Percutaneous Coronary Intervention (PCI).

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to investigate the efficacy and mechanism of Adipokines Cardiac Protection in Obese Patients With acute myocardial infarction (AMI) Who Have Undergone Percutaneous Coronary Intervention (PCI).

detailed_description.textblock: Adipokines (or adipocytokines) can be defined as a group of more than 600 bioactive molecules made from adipose tissue that acts as paracrine and endocrine hormones. Adipokines are involved in maintaining varieties of processes such as, appetite and satiety, energy expenditure activity, endothelial function, blood pressure, hemostasis, adipogenesis, insulin sensitivity, energy metabolism in insulin-sensitive tissues, fat distribution and insulin secretion in pancreatic Î²-cells. Adipokines may contribute to reduce scar formation and improve cardiac function in acute myocardial infarction (AMI). Reperfusion therapy such as percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) should be administered to all eligible patients with AMI symptom onset within the prior 12 hours. However, our previous work showed that obese patients may benefit more from PCI. Thus, the aim of the present study was to investigate the efficacy and mechanism of adipokines cardiac protection for obese and non-obese patients with acute myocardial infarction (AMI) who have undergone PCI.

primary_outcome.measure: Number of patient death during the follow up period

secondary_outcome.measure: Myocardial perfusion scores as evaluated by Single-photon emission computed tomography (SPECT)
Infarct size as evaluated by Single-photon emission computed tomography (SPECT)
Angina class according to the canadian cardiovascular society (CCS) classification
Scores on the Seattle angina questionnaire

study_pop.textblock: Patients of AMI were enrolled in this study.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
age between 20 and 70 years old STEMI and NSTMI according to the WHO definition PCI <12 hours from the onset of symptoms
Exclusion Criteria:
previous myocardial infarction (MI) cardiomyopathy atrial fibrillation or flutter previous heart surgery severe valvular heart disease disease of the hematopoietic system NYHA functional class IV heart failure at baseline severe renal, lung and liver disease cancer
